hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

hashtag#day3 : javaGurugubelli Vijaya Kumar :trainer10000 Coders In Java, operators are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides several types of operators:Arithmetic Operators: Used for basic arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.Example: +, -, *, /, %Relational Operators: Used to compare two values. They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper

They return a boolean value (true or false).Example: ==, !=, >, <, >=, <=Logical Operators: Used to combine multiple boolean expressions.Example: && (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)Assignment Operators: Used to assign values to variables.Example: =, +=, -=, *=, /=

â—¾In Java, data types are classified into two categories: primitive and non-primitive (reference) data types.â—¾Primitive Data Types:Primitive data types are the most basic data types in Java. They are predefined by the language and are used to store simple values.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store actual values.ii. Do not have methods or properties.iii. Fixed size and fast access.iv. Stored in memory directly (stack).â—¾8 Primitive Data Types:i. boolean: Represents true or false.ii. char: 2 bytes, stores a single Unicode character.iii. byte: 1 byte, range from: 128 to 127.iv. short: 2 bytes, range from: 32,768 to 32,767.v. int: 4 bytes, range from: 2^31 to 2^31-1.vi. long: 8 bytes, range from: 2^63 to 2^63-1.vii. float: 4 bytes, floating-point numbers with 6-7 decimal digits.viii. double: 8 bytes, floating-point numbers with 15 decimal digits.â—¾Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types:Non-primitive data types refer to objects or arrays that are created by the programmer. They store references (memory addresses) to the data rather than the actual data.â—¾Characteristics:i. Store references to objects.ii  Can have methods and properties.iii. Stored in heap memory.iv. Default value is null.â—¾Examples of Non-Primitive Data Types:i. Classes: User-defined types such as String, ArrayList, etc.ii  Interfaces: Defines methods that classes must implement.iii. Arrays: A collection of values of the same type.Learn from it and stay connected!hashtag#Java hashtag#Programming hashtag#Beginners hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#JavaDeveloper
